variations.narrative: Water drips somewhere ahead. The passage narrows, walls slick with something that isn't quite water. Your torch pushes back the dark. The dark pushes back.
The corridor bends. You can't see what's around the corner, but you can hear it — a wet, rhythmic sound. Breathing? Dripping? Something else entirely.
Scratch marks line both walls. Something was dragged through here. Recently. The marks lead deeper. So does the only path.
The stone here is older. Worn smooth by countless feet over countless years. You're not the first to walk this path. The bones in the corner suggest you might be among the last.
Your footsteps echo wrong. Too many echoes. As if someone walks beside you, half a step behind. You don't look back. You know better.
A vast space opens before you. Pillars rise into shadow, their tops lost to darkness. This was built for gatherings. Now it gathers only silence. And you.
The ceiling vanishes into black. The walls are too far apart. This room is larger than it should be — larger than the temple above could contain. Geometry lies down here.
Water covers the floor, still as black glass. The chamber stretches in all directions. At its center, something rises from the water. An altar? A throne? You can't tell from here.
Broken pews line the hall. A congregation sat here once, listening to sermons in languages that predate words. The pulpit stands empty. Something watches from behind it.
The chamber hums. A frequency you feel in your teeth, your bones, your thoughts. The walls are carved with patterns that hurt to follow. Don't follow them.
options: Close your eyes and navigate by touch

variations.narrative: Stairs spiral downward. And down. And down. You lose count after the first hundred. The air grows heavier with each step. Warmer. Wrong.
A shaft drops into darkness. Handholds are carved into the stone — worn smooth by countless hands before yours. Some of the holds are stained. Don't think about why.
The floor gives way to a gentle slope. Wet. Slippery. You're descending whether you choose to or not. The gradient steepens. Control is an illusion.
Stone steps, each one lower than the last. The proportions are wrong — built for something with longer legs, or perhaps for humans meant to stumble. You stumble.
The path drops through a crack in the floor. Below, water gleams. How deep? The torch's light doesn't reach the bottom. Nothing does.
options: Drop something to test the depth

variations.narrative: Water to your knees. Black. Cold. Your feet find submerged steps you can't see. Something brushes your leg. Debris, probably. Probably.
The passage is half-drowned. Water reaches your chest if you walk, your neck if you wade through the center. Both options are terrible.
Water rises as you enter. Ankle. Knee. Thigh. It's not flowing in — it's just... rising. As if the room itself is swallowing. Move fast.
Bodies float here. Face down. Bobbing gently. They're not fresh, but they're not old either. The water preserves them. The water preserves everything.
options: Check if any are recent players

variations.narrative: The water glows. Faintly. A sickly phosphorescence that illuminates nothing but itself. Things move beneath the surface. You try not to look directly at them.
An altar to something forgotten. The idol's face has been scratched away, but you feel it watching anyway. Offerings rot at its base. Some are fresh.
Candles burn here. Who lights them? The wax has pooled into shapes — faces, hands, things that might be words in a language of drippings. The flames don't flicker.
A prayer wheel, rusted in place. The prayers carved into it are worn smooth, unreadable. Probably for the best. Someone tried to spin it recently — the rust is scraped.
The shrine is to water itself. A pool, perfectly circular, perfectly still. Your reflection looks back at you. It blinks when you don't.
Names cover every surface. Carved, scratched, burned into stone. Thousands of names. Pilgrims who came before. A blank space waits, as if expecting yours.
Three paths diverge. Left breathes cold air and whispers. Right echoes with distant water. Center shows drag marks leading in. None lead out.
The passage splits. Someone has marked the walls — scratched arrows, desperate directions. The arrows contradict each other. Someone was lost here. Many someones.
A hub of corridors, five in total. Your torch catches movement in two of them. Nothing in the other three — but nothing might be worse.
Up or down. The only choices. Up is harder — the stairs are broken, crumbling. Down is easier. Down is always easier here.
Two identical passages. Same dimensions. Same darkness. Same feeling of wrongness. One leads deeper. One leads to death. They might be the same thing.
Cracks web the ceiling. Dust falls in streams. This place wants to come down. You can hear it debating — groaning, settling, deciding. Move. Now.
Half the passage is rubble. The other half is patience — waiting to become rubble. You can see through to the other side. The gap is narrow. Time is narrower.
The floor tilts. Not much, but enough. Water pools on one side. Cracks spread from where you're standing. Every step is a negotiation with gravity.
Someone triggered a collapse here. You can see where they were standing when it came down. You can see where they stopped standing. Don't stand there.
The walls are bowed inward. Pressure from somewhere. The temple above? The weight of water? The slow crush of the underworld digesting itself? Does it matter? Move.
Bones. Sorted by type — skulls here, ribs there, femurs stacked like firewood. Someone organized this. Recently. There are gaps in the arrangement. Spaces waiting.
Graves line both walls, stacked three high. Some are sealed. Some are open. Some are opening, slowly, from the inside. You don't have time to watch.
A pit of bodies. Old ones, at the bottom. Fresher ones, toward the top. The pit isn't full yet. It's patient. It knows more are coming.
Memorial stones, cracked and worn. Names in languages you don't recognize. Dates that predate calendars. These dead are older than history. They remember anyway.
The dead are posed here. Standing. Sitting. Kneeling. Frozen in their last moments, preserved by the dark. A gallery of endings. Admission is free. Leaving costs more.
The walls are scorched in a pattern. Circular. Precise. At the center, the stone has melted and reformed. Whatever was here is gone. You hope it's gone.
Claw marks cover every surface — floor, walls, ceiling. Deep gouges in solid stone. Something was trying to escape. Or something was trying to get in.
A perfect circle of untouched stone in a room of chaos. The circle is clean. Everything outside it is destroyed. You're standing outside the circle.
Something happened here. The air still tastes like screaming. The stones are warm — warmer than they should be. You're standing in the aftermath of something terrible.
Handprints. Hundreds of them. Pressed into the walls, the floor, the ceiling. All reaching in the same direction. Toward the door you just came through.
The doorway ahead is older than the walls around it. Beyond, the air tastes different — copper and salt. The scratches on the frame point backward. Someone tried to claw their way out.
A boundary. You can feel it — the air pressure changes, the sounds shift, your thoughts briefly scatter. You're about to enter somewhere else. Somewhere deeper.
The passage ends at a curtain of water, falling from somewhere above. Beyond it, darkness. The water is cold. The darkness is colder. Through is the only way.
A gate of bone. Actual bone — ribcages woven together, skulls for hinges. It swings open at your approach. It was waiting for you specifically.
The light from your torch stops at this point. It doesn't illuminate what's beyond — the darkness there is absolute, hungry. You'll have to walk blind for a while.
